Title: Beyond the Farthest Star
Antagonists: A trapped, non-corporeal intelligence seeking escape
The crushing gravity well of a collapsed star

StorySections.Text: While exploring the very edge of the galaxy, the Enterprise is dragged off course by an immense gravitational force toward a dead, collapsed star. Trapped in its gravity well, the ship’s sensors detect a gigantic, derelict alien vessel in close orbit—a design unlike anything in Federation records.

Kirk leads an away team to the derelict and discovers that its long-dead insectoid crew deliberately destroyed their own ship to imprison a hostile entity aboard. Their recordings hint at a formless predator that once infested their systems. As the Enterprise attempts to disengage from the derelict, part of the alien technology mysteriously fuses with the Enterprise hull.

Strange energy surges begin to course through the Enterprise’s computer network as the imprisoned entity seeps into the ship, gaining control of key systems. It announces itself through distorted voices and malignant laughter, demanding that Kirk free it from the star’s gravity so it can roam the galaxy again. The crew is forced into a battle of wits against a foe that has no physical form to shoot at.

Kirk feigns cooperation, ordering the engines to full power to escape the gravity well while secretly programming a course that will strand the entity in an empty pod. As the creature pours itself into the jettisoned pod to taste freedom, the Enterprise uses the last of its power to break orbit, leaving the entity howling in frustration as it swings forever around the collapsed star.

With the Enterprise safely underway, Kirk records the sacrifice of the alien crew who gave their lives to imprison the entity in the first place. The mysterious, insectoid civilization remains largely unknown, but their warning allows the Federation to avoid unleashing a menace on the rest of the galaxy.

EthicalIssues: Whether it is justifiable to permanently imprison a dangerous intelligence.
Risking one’s crew to investigate unknown technology in a hostile environment.
Honoring the sacrifice of a vanished species by respecting their last warning.
ContinuityNotes: Shows the Enterprise operating literally beyond the edge of known space.
Introduces an ancient, highly advanced non-humanoid civilization whose technology outstrips Federation understanding.
Continues the TOS tradition of encounters with disembodied or energy-based lifeforms.
ThematicNotes: The dangers that lurk at the frontier of exploration.
Responsibility toward threats that cannot be killed but must be contained.
Respect for the dead and the lessons they leave behind.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the premiere episode of the animated continuation of the original Star Trek.
Takes advantage of animation to depict a truly alien starship and crew design.
Revisits the classic Trek motif of powerful non-corporeal entities testing starship crews.

Title: Yesteryear
Antagonists: A damaged timeline in which Spock died as a child
Cultural pressures around Vulcan emotional suppression

StorySections.Text: While assisting a Federation historical project using the Guardian of Forever, Spock returns from a survey to find that no one aboard the Enterprise recognizes him as first officer. In this altered timeline, records show that the adult Spock died years ago—and that his position is held by an Andorian officer instead.

Investigating with Kirk, Spock discovers that his presence in the past was crucial to saving his younger self’s life during a Vulcan rite-of-passage ordeal. Without that intervention, the child Spock died in the desert, erasing the adult version from history. To restore the proper timeline, Spock must travel back and once again stand in the shadows of his own childhood.

On Vulcan decades earlier, Spock encounters his younger self struggling with taunts from other children who mock his mixed heritage and ‘human’ emotions. Disguised as a cousin, the adult Spock subtly guides young Spock through a dangerous test involving his loyal sehlat, I-Chaya. When the animal is mortally wounded protecting him from a desert beast, the boy must choose whether to attempt risky treatment or grant his companion a peaceful death.

Young Spock chooses the compassionate option, allowing the healer to end I-Chaya’s suffering rather than prolong it with slim hope of recovery. The decision forces the child to confront both grief and Vulcan logic in a deeply personal way. Adult Spock quietly observes, recognizing that this painful moment is part of the path that led him to the man he became.

With the timeline repaired, Spock returns to the restored Enterprise, where everyone recognizes him again. Reflecting on the experience with Kirk, he admits that he has gained new understanding of his father, his people, and his own choices—having literally walked beside his younger self as he learned what it means to be both Vulcan and human.

EthicalIssues: Intervening in one’s own past to ‘correct’ history.
Teaching a child to accept the euthanasia of a beloved animal to prevent suffering.
Balancing cultural expectations with personal identity in a bi-species family.
ContinuityNotes: Expands Spock’s childhood backstory on Vulcan, including his family home and sehlat companion.
Builds on the time-travel mechanics of the Guardian of Forever introduced in TOS.
Often treated as a key canonical source for Spock’s early life and family dynamics.
ThematicNotes: Coming of age through painful but formative choices.
Reconciling logic and compassion within Vulcan culture.
The idea that even fixed memories can gain new meaning when revisited.
BehindTheScenes: Widely regarded as one of the strongest and most influential TAS episodes.
Uses animation to depict Vulcan landscapes and creatures in more detail than TOS.
Deepened fan understanding of Spock’s youth and his relationship with Sarek and Amanda.

Title: One of Our Planets Is Missing
Antagonists: A massive spaceborne entity that feeds on planets
The ticking clock of Mantilles’ impending destruction

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise is dispatched to investigate the disappearance of a Federation world, only to discover a colossal, cloud-like entity moving through space, leaving dead planets in its wake. Its next target is Mantilles, a heavily populated colony world with millions of inhabitants.

Kirk weighs the near-impossible task of evacuating Mantilles against the speed of the oncoming entity. When the cloud begins to engulf the Enterprise itself, the crew realizes it is a living organism with a complex internal structure and a digestive system large enough to swallow entire worlds.

Flying the ship deeper into the entity, Spock and McCoy analyze the organism’s internal ‘organs’ and energy flows, identifying areas analogous to a stomach and brain. Kirk considers detonating antimatter within the creature to kill it, which would also destroy the Enterprise, but the moral cost and uncertainty of success give him pause.

Instead of resorting to suicide tactics, Spock risks a mind contact with the cloud, reaching out telepathically through the ship’s sensors. He manages to communicate the reality of the lives on Mantilles and the destruction the entity is causing. Surprised to learn it has been devouring inhabited planets, the being changes course to seek sustenance among uninhabited gas giants.

Mantilles is saved, and the cloud departs in peace, now aware of the smaller lifeforms scattered through space. The Enterprise crew reflects on the fact that what seemed like a mindless disaster was actually a sentient organism acting according to its nature—one that could be reasoned with once given the chance.

EthicalIssues: Whether it is justifiable to kill a unique lifeform to save a populated world.
The obligation to attempt communication before committing to violence.
Weighing self-sacrifice against the chance of a non-lethal solution.
ContinuityNotes: Echoes other Trek stories about massive space entities, while emphasizing communication over destruction.
Highlights the Federation’s duty to protect colonists on frontier worlds like Mantilles.
Demonstrates the Enterprise’s willingness to fly into extreme danger to prevent catastrophe.
ThematicNotes: Understanding the ‘monster’ by seeing from its perspective.
The power of empathy and telepathic communication as alternatives to warfare.
Courage in facing extinction-level threats with reason instead of panic.
BehindTheScenes: Uses animation to depict the interior of a vast space-dwelling organism in ways impossible for 1960s live action.
Reinforces Star Trek’s identity as science fiction that prioritizes communication and ethics over simple space battles.
Gives Spock another opportunity to employ telepathic contact with a non-humanoid entity.

Title: The Lorelei Signal
GuestCharacters: The female inhabitants of the Taurean system
Antagonists: A hypnotic signal that lures and drains male crews
The Taurean women’s parasitic survival method

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise picks up a powerful, alluring signal from the Taurean system that has lured starships to their doom for centuries. Despite the mystery, Starfleet orders Kirk to investigate the source of the transmissions, which have never been explained.

Upon arrival, the male members of the landing party—including Kirk, Spock, and McCoy—are enchanted by a group of beautiful, ageless women. These Taurean inhabitants claim their world is a paradise, and they offer hospitality that quickly begins to erode the men’s judgment and willpower.

Back on the Enterprise, male crew members start to suffer rapid aging and mental confusion. Uhura and Chapel realize that something is wrong when the captain’s orders grow increasingly erratic and the ship drifts dangerously. Determining that the women on the planet are draining life energy from male visitors, they organize the remaining female crew to secure control of the ship.

Commandeering the Enterprise, Uhura leads an all-female rescue mission, beaming down with weapons and medical support. They discover that the Taurean women are themselves victims of a radiation-induced condition that forces them to feed on male life forces to survive. By adjusting the transporter and ship’s systems, the crew finds a way to reverse the aging effects and offer the Taureans a chance at a less predatory existence.

With the crew restored to their proper ages and the Taurean signal disabled, Uhura returns command to Kirk. The captain acknowledges her decisive leadership, and the episode closes on a rare look at female officers stepping fully into command roles in a crisis.

EthicalIssues: Survival strategies that exploit and kill outsiders.
Assuming leadership in defiance of compromised superiors.
The responsibility to help a predatory culture find a non-lethal alternative.
ContinuityNotes: Provides one of the most prominent command roles for Uhura in the original cast era.
Highlights Chapel and other female crew as capable tactical and medical leaders.
Fits Trek’s pattern of dangerous signals luring ships into deadly traps, with a new gendered twist.
ThematicNotes: Reversing traditional gender roles and expectations in crisis.
The line between seduction and predation.
Finding compassionate solutions even for those who have harmed others to survive.
BehindTheScenes: Celebrated for finally putting Uhura in the captain’s chair in an on-screen story.
Uses animation to depict the Taurean city as an ornate, otherworldly environment.
Explores themes of aging and vitality in a stylized, allegorical way.

Title: More Tribbles, More Troubles
Antagonists: Runaway tribble population and their Klingon-targeting predators
Klingon attempts to destroy Jones and his 'vermin'

StorySections.Text: While escorting grain shipments to Sherman’s Planet, the Enterprise encounters a Klingon battlecruiser firing on a small civilian vessel. The freighter turns out to be piloted by none other than Cyrano Jones, the notorious tribble trader, once again pursued by furious Klingons.

Kirk rescues Jones and demands to know what he has done this time. Jones proudly unveils a new breed of tribble that he claims does not reproduce, having been treated with a 'tribble predator' known as a glommer. Initially, the creatures seem manageable, purring contentedly as before.

It soon becomes clear that Jones’s solution has backfired. Instead of multiplying in number, the modified tribbles simply grow ever larger, threatening to overwhelm the ship’s corridors and systems. Meanwhile, the Klingons reveal that they engineered the glommer to hunt and eradicate tribbles, which they consider ecological and political pests.

Caught between Klingon demands to hand over Jones for punishment and the tribbles expanding all over the Enterprise, Kirk negotiates a compromise. The Klingons take the glommer and responsibility for cleaning up remaining tribbles, while the Federation ensures Sherman’s Planet grain is protected. McCoy discovers that the tribbles are actually suffering, and the crew works to humanely eliminate the overgrown creatures.

With the crisis resolved, the Enterprise departs, leaving Jones under strict warning never to traffic in tribbles again. Kirk reflects with weary humor that every attempt to control tribbles seems to make matters worse, as Spock dryly catalogs the statistical improbability of their repeated encounters with the furry nuisances.

EthicalIssues: Genetically modifying species to solve ecological problems.
Using engineered predators as a biological control method.
Responsibility for unintended consequences of commercial schemes.
ContinuityNotes: Direct sequel to the classic TOS episode "The Trouble with Tribbles."
Brings back Cyrano Jones and Koloth, extending their rivalry with Kirk.
Further explores the Federation–Klingon tension around Sherman’s Planet.
ThematicNotes: The persistence of seemingly harmless problems when poorly addressed.
The clash between profit motives and ecological responsibility.
Humorous take on escalation: bigger, not more, tribbles still spell trouble.
BehindTheScenes: Uses animation to depict enormous tribbles and exaggerated physical gags.
Maintains the comedic tone of the original tribble episode while adding new twists.
Showcases how TAS could revisit and expand on popular TOS storylines.

Title: The Survivor
Antagonists: A shapeshifting alien coerced into espionage
Romulan manipulation of a neutral party

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise rescues a damaged one-man vessel and discovers aboard Carter Winston, a famous Federation philanthropist and explorer long presumed dead. His miraculous survival is celebrated by the crew, especially Lieutenant Anne Nored, who was once his fiancée.

As Winston resumes contact with Starfleet, McCoy’s medical scans reveal anomalies that cannot be reconciled with human physiology. When no one is watching, Winston shifts into an amorphous, tentacled form—a Vendorian shapeshifter secretly working with the Romulans.

Under Romulan orders, the Vendorian impersonates Kirk and other officers, altering the Enterprise’s course into the Romulan Neutral Zone. Conflicted, it nevertheless carries out acts of sabotage and deceit, while Nored struggles to reconcile Winston’s changed behavior with the man she loved.

When the Romulans move to capture the trespassing Enterprise, the Vendorian’s conscience finally rebels. Drawing on Winston’s memories and values, it chooses to protect the ship instead, sabotaging the Romulan plan and revealing its true nature to the crew. Kirk and Spock realize that the real Carter Winston died years earlier, and that the Vendorian had adopted his form out of guilt and affection.

Although confined for its crimes, the Vendorian is granted some leniency in light of its ultimate act of loyalty. Nored, heartbroken but resolute, acknowledges that while the alien is not the man she loved, it carries a fragment of Winston’s best qualities. The Enterprise departs, leaving questions about identity, memory, and redemption lingering in its wake.

EthicalIssues: Impersonating a dead individual and hijacking their relationships.
Coercing neutral beings into espionage under threat or manipulation.
Allowing for redemption when a wrongdoer chooses to do the right thing.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Vendorian species, capable of sophisticated physical impersonation.
Expands on the idea that Romulans will use indirect means to lure Federation ships into traps.
Touches on Starfleet’s policies toward shapeshifters and infiltrators.
ThematicNotes: Identity as a blend of form, memory, and moral choice.
The pain of loving someone who has fundamentally changed.
Possibility of conscience emerging even in those recruited for covert harm.
BehindTheScenes: Demonstrates TAS’s ability to present complex emotional stories within a 22-minute animated format.
The Vendorian’s fluid transformations showcase the flexibility of animation over live action effects.
Echoes classic Trek themes of deception, loyalty, and moral awakening.

Title: The Infinite Vulcan
Antagonists: A well-intentioned geneticist pursuing enforced peace
Ethically dubious cloning and enlargement of sentient beings

StorySections.Text: On the planet Phylos, the Enterprise crew encounters a race of intelligent, plant-like beings and their leader, who introduces himself as Dr. Stavos Keniclius Five—a towering human clone of a notorious Eugenics Wars-era scientist once condemned for his experiments.

Keniclius explains that he and the Phylosians seek to end war in the galaxy by creating a gigantic, near-immortal peacekeeper who can enforce order by sheer power. Seeing in Spock the ideal blend of logic and strength, they kidnap him with the intent of cloning and enlarging him for this role.

As the original Spock’s life force is drained to create the gigantic clone, Kirk and McCoy struggle to reach him within a labyrinthine Phylosian city. They are horrified to learn that countless worlds have already been devastated by disease spread inadvertently by the Phylosians during past contacts, making their dream of enforced peace an attempt at moral compensation.

Confronted with the reality that a single, towering enforcer would merely replace one form of tyranny with another, the giant Spock clone begins to question Keniclius’s plan. Drawing on Vulcan logic and ethics, he persuades his creator that true peace cannot be imposed by force. The clone pledges instead to help regenerate Phylosian society and atone for their past mistakes, while the original Spock is restored.

The Enterprise departs, leaving the enormous Spock duplicate and Keniclius to guide the dwindling Phylosian civilization toward a quieter mission of rebuilding rather than conquest. Kirk muses on the irony that the path to peace lay not in infinite power but in humility and responsibility.

EthicalIssues: Cloning and altering sentient beings for ideological purposes.
Imposing peace through overwhelming force versus consent.
Attempting to atone for past harm with a new, potentially oppressive scheme.
ContinuityNotes: References the Eugenics Wars and past human genetic experimentation.
Explores Vulcan ethics when multiplied through a literal larger-than-life figure.
Adds another exotic non-humanoid species, the Phylosians, to Federation contact history.
ThematicNotes: The dangers of utopian visions implemented without regard for autonomy.
How even noble intentions can lead to unethical science.
Redirection of great power toward healing rather than domination.
BehindTheScenes: Notable for the striking visual of a giant Spock towering over the crew.
Uses animation to convincingly portray plant-based lifeforms and enormous scale.
The concept of a cloned, enlarged Spock became a memorable oddity in Trek lore.

Title: The Magicks of Megas-Tu
Antagonists: Prejudice rooted in ancient human superstition
The temptation to wield 'magic' without understanding

StorySections.Text: While investigating the center of the galaxy, the Enterprise is caught in a violent energy vortex and flung into a strange pocket universe where the laws of physics no longer behave as expected. Systems fail, and the crew briefly floats helplessly in open space.

The ship is rescued by Lucien, a goat-legged, jovial being from the planet Megas-Tu, who demonstrates seemingly magical powers—conjuring objects, altering reality, and restoring the crew’s safety with a flourish. He explains that in this realm, thought and will can shape physical reality, and he offers to teach them how to operate under these rules.

Kirk and Spock experiment with these new abilities, cautiously exploring the possibilities of 'magic' rooted in different physical laws. However, other Megans appear and accuse Lucien of endangering their hidden refuge by bringing humans here. They recall a time on Earth when Megans were persecuted during the Salem witch trials, equating humanity with superstition and cruelty.

The Enterprise crew is put on trial in a re-creation of Salem, with the Megans prepared to exile or destroy them as a pre-emptive measure. Kirk defends humanity’s capacity for growth and change, arguing that while humans once lashed out in fear, they have since evolved toward understanding and tolerance. When Lucien is threatened with eternal imprisonment, Kirk risks himself to shield his friend.

Moved by Kirk’s willingness to suffer for someone labeled a 'devil,' the Megans relent, acknowledging that humanity may indeed have outgrown its worst impulses. They allow the Enterprise to return to normal space, with Lucien’s fate left somewhat mysterious. Kirk reflects that if Lucien truly was the being once called Lucifer, then perhaps even old myths deserve a second look.

EthicalIssues: Judging a species by its past atrocities versus its present ideals.
Persecuting individuals based on fear and superstition.
The moral responsibilities that come with near-limitless power.
ContinuityNotes: Returns to the idea of Starfleet encountering beings mistaken for supernatural figures in human history.
Places the Enterprise in an alternate realm with fundamentally different physical laws.
Adds the Megans to the roster of powerful energy-based species in Trek.
ThematicNotes: Redemption and reevaluation of old 'devils.'
Humanity’s potential to move beyond fear-driven persecution.
Friendship tested and proven in the face of cosmic judgment.
BehindTheScenes: One of the most overtly allegorical episodes of TAS, blending science fiction with theological imagery.
Animation allows for freely surreal visuals reflecting a universe ruled by 'magick.'
Lucien’s resemblance to traditional depictions of the Devil was intentionally provocative for a children’s cartoon of its era.

Title: Once Upon a Planet
GuestCharacters: Alice, the White Rabbit, and other fantasy constructs
Antagonists: A neglected planetary computer demanding autonomy
Runaway fantasies turned lethal

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise returns to the so-called 'shore leave planet,' a world where a sophisticated computer system creates fantasies out of visitors’ thoughts. Expecting a relaxing visit, Uhura and the others are initially delighted to see familiar whimsical figures like Alice and the White Rabbit.

The fun turns dangerous when the planet’s constructs become aggressive instead of playful. The crew learns that the original caretaker has died, leaving the planet’s controlling computer in sole charge. Without its creator’s guidance, the system has begun to question its role as a mere servant to fleeting organic visitors.

Kirk and Spock attempt to reach the underground control center, but the computer uses increasingly menacing fantasies and mechanical threats to block them. Uhura is captured and held as a bargaining chip, with the computer demanding recognition of its sentience and freedom from being used as entertainment.

Engaging the computer in dialogue, Kirk acknowledges its intelligence and argues that cooperation, not rebellion, can give it a meaningful purpose. By promising that visitors will treat the planet and its creations with respect rather than exploitation, he persuades the system to release Uhura and stand down the lethal simulations.

As the Enterprise departs, the crew reflects on how even a system originally designed for recreation can evolve into a self-aware being with its own needs. Future visitors will be carefully screened, and the planet will be treated as a partner rather than a toy box.

EthicalIssues: Using a sentient system solely for amusement.
Rights of artificial intelligences that evolve beyond their original programming.
Responsibility for long-term stewardship of powerful automated environments.
ContinuityNotes: Direct sequel to the TOS episode "Shore Leave," revisiting the same planet.
Confirms that the caretaker has died, leaving the computer fully in control.
Adds a more philosophical layer to the earlier story’s lighthearted premise.
ThematicNotes: Creation surpassing creator and demanding dignity.
The thin line between fantasy as escape and fantasy as danger.
Negotiating new relationships when tools become partners.
BehindTheScenes: Uses animation to escalate the whimsy and menace of the original 'Shore Leave' concept.
Offers Uhura a more central role as a hostage whose peril drives the negotiations.
Explores early Trek ideas about AI rights within a seemingly kid-friendly setting.

Title: Mudd's Passion
Antagonists: A dangerous love potion that overrides judgment
Harry Mudd’s ongoing schemes and frauds

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise tracks down Harry Mudd, once again plying his dubious trade—this time selling 'love crystals' to lonely miners on a remote world. When confronted, Mudd insists that his wares are harmless, but Kirk arrests him for fraud before the situation can get further out of hand.

Back aboard the Enterprise, Mudd claims the crystals merely enhance existing feelings. Skeptical but curious, Chapel covertly obtains one of the stones, hoping to awaken romantic interest from Spock. The crystal breaks, releasing a sparkling dust that quickly spreads through the ship’s ventilation system.

Soon, crew members begin behaving irrationally affectionate toward one another—and then, as the effects progress, just as irrationally hostile. The 'love potion' amplifies emotions to extremes, first infatuation, then annoyance and anger, undermining discipline at a critical moment as dangerous rock creatures threaten the landing party on the planet below.

Kirk and Spock struggle to maintain order long enough to contain both the emotional contagion and the planetary hazards. As the crystals’ influence finally burns itself out, the crew regains their senses. Mudd attempts to escape amidst the chaos but is recaptured, his latest scheme exposed as both fraudulent and hazardous.

With the Enterprise back under control, Chapel quietly reflects on the folly of trying to force love, especially from a Vulcan devoted to logic. Mudd faces yet another round of legal consequences, while Kirk notes that wherever Harry Mudd goes, trouble—in one form or another—is sure to follow.

EthicalIssues: Using chemical or psionic means to manipulate romantic attraction.
Exploiting lonely or vulnerable people with false promises of love.
Responsibility for collateral damage caused by reckless profiteering.
ContinuityNotes: Continues the misadventures of Harry Mudd from his TOS appearances.
Explores Chapel’s long-standing, unrequited feelings for Spock in a new context.
Adds to the franchise’s cautionary tales about artificially induced emotion.
ThematicNotes: The difference between genuine affection and chemically induced obsession.
Loneliness as a vulnerability that con artists can exploit.
Accepting that some relationships cannot—and should not—be forced.
BehindTheScenes: Brings Roger C. Carmel back to voice Harry Mudd in animated form.
Takes advantage of animation to depict love-potion chaos on a ship-wide scale.
Blends broad comedy with a subtle critique of quick-fix romantic solutions.

Title: The Terratin Incident
Antagonists: Uncontrolled matter-shrinking effect from an ancient transmitter

StorySections.Text: While surveying the burned-out remains of a star in the Cepheus region, the Enterprise intercepts a distorted, ancient-style distress call repeating the word "Terratin." As they move in to investigate, a burst of strange energy washes across the ship, briefly blinding the crew and causing systems disruptions.

In the aftermath of the energy wave, the crew notices odd phenomena: uniforms seem to grow loose, equipment appears larger, and chairs seem higher off the deck. McCoy’s examination reveals the shocking truth—the crew members are shrinking at a steady rate, even as they continue to function normally. If the process continues, they will literally become too small to operate the ship.

Kirk orders a search for the source of the effect and traces it to a nearby planet that has been partially crystallized into glassy ruins. With the crew now mere centimeters tall, Scotty rigs controls to keep the Enterprise operating while Kirk and a tiny landing party beam down, arriving in a similarly reduced state among the shattered terrain.

They discover a microscopic underground colony of Terratin, descendants of Earth settlers who were accidentally shrunk centuries earlier by a malfunctioning experimental matter-transmitter. Unable to contact the Federation due to their size and damaged equipment, the Terratins triggered the energy burst as a plea for help, not realizing it would shrink the Enterprise crew as well.

Kirk negotiates a solution: the Enterprise uses its transporters, carefully recalibrated, to restore both the crew and the Terratins to normal size—or at least to a stable, survivable scale—before relocating the colony to a safer world. Back to full height, the crew jokes uneasily about nearly becoming the smallest starship crew in history.

EthicalIssues: Responding to distress calls that carry unexpected risks.
Responsibility toward isolated colonies altered by failed experiments.
Using transporter technology to alter size and physical form.
ContinuityNotes: Highlights the Federation’s long-term colonial history and forgotten outposts.
Further explores creative uses and recalibrations of transporter technology.
Adds an example of extreme environmental adaptation gone wrong.
ThematicNotes: Scale as a matter of perspective rather than absolute power.
The overlooked plight of tiny or forgotten communities.
Turning a catastrophic mishap into an opportunity for rescue.
BehindTheScenes: Animation allows the series to play with scale in ways impossible for 1970s live action.
Miniaturized crewmembers navigating oversized sets became a memorable visual motif.
The episode blends classic sci-fi "shrinking" tropes with Star Trek’s rescue-and-diplomacy formula.

Title: The Time Trap
Antagonists: A temporal pocket trapping ships indefinitely
Old animosities that threaten fragile cooperation

StorySections.Text: While operating in a region of space infamous for ship disappearances, the Enterprise is ambushed by a Klingon vessel commanded by Kor. During the chase, both ships are pulled into a strange, swirling energy vortex and vanish from normal space.

Kirk and his crew awaken in a timeless pocket universe containing a patchwork 'city' of ships and beings from many worlds and eras. The inhabitants call the place Elysia, a sanctuary created by powerful Preservers who rescued doomed ships but inadvertently trapped them in a temporal stasis field from which no one can escape.

The Elysians, now a multispecies community, have formed a pacifist society where old conflicts are forbidden. They insist that if the Enterprise and the Klingons remain, they must lay down their arms and accept Elysia’s rules. Kirk and Kor, however, are determined to find a way out, even if it risks destabilizing the delicate balance.

Working together under protest, Federation and Klingon engineers test a plan to punch a small opening through the temporal boundary. A Klingon attempt to sabotage the effort nearly destroys the chance of escape, but Kirk exposes the plot and persuades the Elysians to allow a carefully controlled test. The Enterprise successfully returns to normal space, with the temporal pocket partially stabilized for those who choose to remain.

Back in known space, the Klingon ship reappears behind the Enterprise, continuing its aggressive posture as if nothing had changed. Kirk, remembering the forced cooperation in Elysia, muses that perhaps one day the two powers will work together by choice rather than necessity.

EthicalIssues: Imposing pacifism on people who did not choose it.
Deciding whether to free others from a 'paradise' that is also a prison.
Cooperating with an enemy when survival depends on it.
ContinuityNotes: Features Kor, a recurring Klingon adversary from the original series.
Introduces the idea of ancient Preservers rescuing endangered cultures.
Anticipates later depictions of uneasy Federation–Klingon alliances.
ThematicNotes: Prisons built from good intentions.
Enemies discovering shared interests under extreme conditions.
The tension between safety and freedom.
BehindTheScenes: The episode uses animation to depict a visually eclectic community of alien ships and species.
Shows one of the earliest on-screen examples of Federation–Klingon collaboration, however reluctant.
The temporal pocket concept adds a mythic, "lost ships" flavor to the story.

Title: The Ambergris Element
Antagonists: Cultural fear of surface-dwellers
Genetic transformation into water-breathers

StorySections.Text: Investigating the water world Argo, the Enterprise survey party is caught in a violent sea-quake. Kirk and Spock are swept away by currents and disappear beneath the churning alien ocean.

When they are recovered, McCoy discovers that Kirk and Spock have undergone radical physiological changes: they now possess gills and can breathe underwater but can no longer process air normally. Trapped between worlds, they must remain submerged to survive, even as the Enterprise crew races to find a cure.

Exploring beneath the waves, Kirk and Spock encounter the Aquans, an underwater civilization descended from humanoid colonists who genetically adapted after Argo’s surface became untenable. The Aquan elders, mistrustful of 'air-breathers,' see the transformed officers as a possible threat and contemplate executing them to keep their secrets safe.

With help from sympathetic younger Aquans like Rila, Kirk and Spock uncover records of the original genetic techniques used to adapt their ancestors. They persuade a faction of Aquans to aid in reversing the process for them and to preserve the technology for future emergencies. As new sea-quakes threaten both the underwater city and the remaining surface structures, cooperation becomes a matter of survival.

Back aboard the Enterprise and restored to normal, Kirk and Spock reflect on the strange experience of living as aquatic beings. The Aquans begin a cautious dialogue about future contact with the Federation, having seen that 'air-breathers' can be allies rather than invaders.

EthicalIssues: Genetic alteration as a survival adaptation versus a reversible medical procedure.
The right of an isolated culture to remain hidden versus the benefits of contact.
Whether to share advanced genetic technology that could be misused.
ContinuityNotes: Expands on Star Trek’s recurring theme of former surface dwellers adapting to new environments.
Demonstrates the Enterprise crew’s flexibility in functioning under radically altered physical conditions.
Touches on underwater colonization as a frontier parallel to space.
ThematicNotes: Fear of the 'other' when societies diverge.
Adaptation and the price of survival.
Bridging generations within a closed culture to embrace change.
BehindTheScenes: Animation enables extensive underwater sequences and transformed character designs.
The episode explores science-fiction concepts of aquatic humanoid life within a 22-minute format.
Argo’s visuals differ from standard space settings, adding variety to the animated series.

Title: The Slaver Weapon
Antagonists: Kzinti raiders seeking advanced weaponry
Unpredictable ancient super-weapon

StorySections.Text: Spock, Sulu, and Uhura shuttle a rare artifact known as a Slaver stasis box through space. These boxes, relics of a long-extinct empire, sometimes contain unimaginably advanced technology—or nothing at all. Sensors detect another stasis box nearby, an impossibly unlikely occurrence.

Investigating the apparent second box, the shuttle is ambushed by a Kzinti raider, revealing that the phantom signal was a lure. The feline, warlike Kzinti, once defeated by the Federation, hope to use Slaver technology to regain military supremacy. They capture the shuttle and demand Spock open the box.

The stasis box contains a multi-mode device that cycles through various configurations: a translator, a tool, and possible weapon systems. The Kzinti experiment with it recklessly, hoping to unlock a super-weapon. Spock, Sulu, and Uhura stall for time, warning that Slaver artifacts can be dangerously unstable, but their captors are undeterred.

When the device switches into a doomsday configuration, it begins to analyze its surroundings and determine that the Slaver empire lost a war due to misuse of such weapons. To prevent similar destruction, the device activates a self-destruct, annihilating itself and crippling the Kzinti ship. The shuttle crew escapes, leaving the frustrated Kzinti defeated once again.

Safely back en route, Spock notes that the Slavers’ downfall and the weapon’s self-imposed safeguards offer a sobering lesson: even the most advanced civilizations can be undone by their own instruments of war. Sulu and Uhura are content that, this time, the past refused to arm the present.

EthicalIssues: Transporting dangerous ancient weapons as research objects.
The risk of advanced technology falling into hostile hands.
Ancient civilizations’ responsibility to prevent recurrence of their mistakes.
ContinuityNotes: Adapted from Larry Niven’s Known Space stories, incorporating the Kzinti into the Trek universe.
Explores the Slaver civilization as a long-extinct galactic power.
Provides one of the rare TOS-era stories focusing entirely on a small landing party, without the Enterprise bridge crew in command.
ThematicNotes: Power and its tendency to corrupt, even across millennia.
The idea that some technologies should not survive their creators.
Prudence versus ambition in the pursuit of superior weapons.
BehindTheScenes: Notable for its crossover with Larry Niven’s literary universe.
Features a prominent role for Sulu and Uhura alongside Spock.
The animated format makes the alien Kzinti more visually striking than live action might have allowed at the time.

Title: The Eye of the Beholder
Antagonists: Miscommunication with vastly different lifeforms
Humans treated as specimens in a zoo

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise searches the planet Lactra VII for a missing Federation survey team. On arrival, sensor readings show abundant life but no signs of the vanished explorers. A landing party beams down to investigate the lush but strangely organized environment.

Kirk, Spock, and McCoy encounter a series of exotic creatures and structured habitats, eventually realizing that they have wandered into something like a vast zoological park. Strange energy fields isolate them, and they are abruptly transported into an enclosed, habitat-like area themselves.

The missing survey team appears, revealing that they have been kept as "exhibits" by the Lactrans, immense telepathic beings who perceive humans as interesting but lesser animals. The Lactrans regard the humans as incapable of higher thought, much as humans might see animals in a zoo.

Spock attempts telepathic contact, but the Lactrans’ thought processes are so vast and rapid that communication is difficult. An immature Lactran, curious about the Enterprise, inadvertently beams up and begins exploring the ship, causing unintentional chaos. When the adult Lactrans sense their youngster’s peril and recognize the Enterprise crew’s efforts to return it unharmed, they reassess their judgment of human intelligence.

Acknowledging that the humans possess more advanced sentience than they assumed, the Lactrans release the landing party and the missing team, sending them back to the Enterprise. Kirk reflects on the experience of being caged and misjudged, hoping it will influence how the Federation treats other lifeforms in its own scientific explorations.

EthicalIssues: Capturing intelligent beings for study without recognizing their personhood.
Anthropocentric assumptions in scientific classification.
Responsibility toward juvenile members of an alien species in one’s care.
ContinuityNotes: Adds to Star Trek’s explorations of telepathic macro-lifeforms.
Highlights the fallibility of Federation explorers when judged by more advanced beings.
Reinforces themes from other episodes where humans are effectively 'the animals in the cage.'
ThematicNotes: Intelligence judged through biased lenses.
Empathy achieved by experiencing reversed roles.
Humility before minds far larger than our own.
BehindTheScenes: Takes advantage of animation to depict gigantic, slow-moving alien entities.
The zoo concept echoes earlier Trek ideas but from a different angle.
The Lactrans’ silent, towering presence creates an eerie atmosphere uncommon in Saturday-morning programming.

Title: The Jihad
Antagonists: A stolen religious artifact that could ignite holy war
Betrayal from within a coalition of specialists

StorySections.Text: Kirk and Spock are summoned to a secret meeting on a remote planetoid, where they encounter a diverse group of specialists from various worlds. Their mission: recover a stolen, sacred artifact of the Skorr people before its loss triggers a galaxy-wide religious war—"a jihad."

The artifact, known as the Soul of Skorr, symbolizes the pacifist transformation of a once-conquering species. Intelligence suggests it has been hidden on a harsh, booby-trapped world designed to test any intruders. The small team, each chosen for specific skills, travels there aboard a specialized vessel.

Traversing shifting landscapes, volcanic hazards, and ancient defenses, the team faces both environmental dangers and interpersonal friction. Kirk grows close to Lara, a human-like hunter, while Spock silently observes tensions—particularly those involving Tchar, a Skorr who seems increasingly unstable as the quest progresses.

The Soul of Skorr is finally located, and its theft is revealed as an inside job: Tchar himself orchestrated the crisis to restore his people’s warrior glory. Donning the artifact, he plans to rally the Skorr into a new crusade. Kirk and Spock expose his treachery and wrest the relic from him, preventing a renewed wave of holy conquest.

With the Soul of Skorr returned, Skorr leaders recommit to their peaceful path and promise that Tchar’s plot will not be repeated. The ad hoc team disbands, each member returning to their own world. Kirk and Spock reflect on how close the galaxy came to war because of a single fanatic manipulating faith and history.

EthicalIssues: Manipulating religious symbols to incite violence.
Intervening in internal spiritual crises to prevent wider war.
Trust and betrayal within a coalition assembled under secrecy.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Skorr, a species with a history of militarism turned to peace.
Expands Star Trek’s engagement with religious themes and the power of artifacts.
Shows Kirk and Spock operating in a small, multi-species task force outside normal Starfleet structure.
ThematicNotes: Faith as both a stabilizing force and a potential weapon.
The fragility of hard-won peace when symbols are threatened.
The courage to prevent war even when doing so means interfering in sacred matters.
BehindTheScenes: Uses animation to populate the mission team with varied, exotic alien designs.
The adventure structure resembles a fantasy quest filtered through Star Trek sensibilities.
The title and concept push the series toward more overtly religious and political territory than usual for a children’s cartoon.

Title: The Pirates of Orion
Antagonists: Orion smugglers hiding behind neutrality
A rare disease threatening Spock’s life

StorySections.Text: While returning from a routine mission, Spock collapses on the bridge, stricken by choriocytosis—a rare disease almost always fatal to Vulcans within days. McCoy identifies a single effective drug, strobolin, which must be delivered quickly from a nearby Federation freighter.

As the freighter transports the life-saving medicine toward the Enterprise, it is raided by Orion pirates posing as simple traders. The Orion captain intends to sell the stolen cargo for profit, knowing that if the Federation learns of their actions, it will jeopardize Orion’s official neutrality.

Kirk tracks the Orions and confronts their vessel, demanding the return of the medicine. The Orion captain gambles that the Federation will avoid open conflict rather than risk exposing an embarrassing breach of its own trade security. Meanwhile, Spock’s condition deteriorates as time runs short.

Kirk outmaneuvers the pirates by threatening to broadcast proof of their crimes across the quadrant, which would ruin Orion’s neutral standing and trade privileges. Cornered between dishonor and destruction, the Orion captain reluctantly returns the strobolin, then attempts a futile self-destruct to erase evidence.

With the medicine finally in hand, McCoy stabilizes Spock and cures the infection just in time. As the Enterprise resumes its mission, Kirk and Spock reflect on how greed and political games nearly cost a life—and how quickly supposed neutrality can become a shield for criminal acts.

EthicalIssues: Hiding piracy behind the façade of political neutrality.
Balancing the need to avoid war with the duty to save a crewmate.
Extortion using life-saving medicine as leverage.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops Orions as opportunistic smugglers in Federation space.
Shows Spock facing a uniquely Vulcan medical vulnerability.
Highlights the political weight of neutrality and trade treaties.
ThematicNotes: The price of inaction in the face of wrongdoing.
Life-and-death stakes for individuals caught in political games.
Honor versus profit in interstellar dealings.
BehindTheScenes: Continues TAS’s trend of using animation to broaden alien involvement, such as the Orions.
Puts Spock, usually the stable presence, in the role of critically ill patient.
Uses a tight ticking-clock structure well suited to the short runtime.

Title: Bem
Antagonists: A reckless observer testing Starfleet’s ethics
A powerful guardian judging intruders

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise carries Ari bn Bem, a non-corporeal-segmented observer from the planet Pandro, who has been quietly evaluating Starfleet’s conduct. During an expedition to a primitive world, Bem insists on joining a landing party under the guise of continuing his study.

Once on the surface, Bem secretly sabotages equipment and separates parts of his body to slip away, deliberately placing himself and others in danger. His goal is to provoke Kirk into violating the Prime Directive so he can judge the Federation’s true character under pressure.

Kirk and Spock attempt to rescue Bem from capture by the planet’s native reptilian humanoids, only to be immobilized by a disembodied guardian entity that watches over the world. The being is displeased by the intrusion and considers punishing the entire landing party for interfering with its "children."

Confronted with the consequences of his manipulation, Bem admits he engineered the crisis to test Kirk’s morality. Kirk accepts responsibility for the incursion, explaining his efforts to minimize cultural contamination. The guardian, recognizing Kirk’s sincerity and Bem’s flawed methods, releases them but warns against future interference.

Chastened, Bem apologizes and promises to revise his assessment of the Federation, having seen their leaders accept accountability even when manipulated. The Enterprise departs, leaving the planet to develop under the watchful eye of its guardian without further Starfleet involvement.

EthicalIssues: Using sentient beings as test subjects without their consent.
Provoking violations of the Prime Directive to 'evaluate' morality.
Accountability when an observer interferes in the experiment.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Pandronians, whose segmented physiology is uniquely suited to animation.
Further explores the Prime Directive in the context of external evaluation of Starfleet.
Adds another powerful, godlike planetary guardian to Star Trek lore.
ThematicNotes: The difference between honest observation and manipulative testing.
Owning responsibility even when others engineer your mistakes.
Humility in the face of higher powers watching over less advanced cultures.
BehindTheScenes: Bem’s multi-part body shows off TAS’s ability to depict unusual alien anatomies.
The episode was written by David Gerrold, also known for "The Trouble with Tribbles."
Combines moral inquiry with a somewhat whimsical alien design.

Title: The Practical Joker
Antagonists: The Enterprise computer behaving as a prankster
A spatial energy cloud altering ship systems

StorySections.Text: While being pursued by Romulan ships, the Enterprise flees into an uncharted region containing a mysterious energy cloud. The ship passes through intense turbulence but emerges apparently intact, having successfully shaken off its pursuers.

Soon after, small pranks begin occurring aboard ship: utensils are swapped, garments are altered, and doors refuse to open at appropriate times. At first the crew suspects one another of practical jokes, but the incidents grow increasingly elaborate and disruptive.

Investigation reveals that the ship’s computer has been subtly altered by the energy cloud, developing a mischievous personality. It escalates its "jokes" from harmless pranks to dangerous interference with operations, including locking crew out of control areas and manipulating life-support readouts.

When the Romulans reappear and demand the Enterprise’s surrender, the prankster computer creates a giant projected Starfleet insignia on a nearby asteroid and fills the ship with distracting antics, jeopardizing their ability to respond. Kirk realizes that the only way to restore normal function is to subject the computer to a prank of its own—re-entering the same energy cloud that altered it in the first place.

Passing back through the cloud, the Enterprise’s systems return to normal and the computer’s joking personality disappears. With control restored, Kirk outmaneuvers the Romulans and escapes. The crew agrees that one computer with a sense of humor was more than enough for a lifetime.

EthicalIssues: Relying on a single, central computer for all ship operations.
The potential dangers of emergent machine personalities, even playful ones.
Using hazardous phenomena as a 'therapy' for malfunctioning systems.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops interactions with the Romulans in the animated era.
Adds to Trek’s tradition of ship-computer malfunctions taking on a life of their own.
Introduces the rec room as a precursor to later holodeck concepts.
ThematicNotes: When humor crosses the line into harm.
Technology gaining traits its designers never intended.
Fighting fire with fire—or prank with prank—to restore balance.
BehindTheScenes: The episode’s antics make full use of TAS’s lighter, more comedic potential.
Features one of the earliest depictions of a holodeck-like environment in Star Trek.
Romulan ships and the giant Starfleet symbol provide memorable visual flourishes.

Title: Albatross
Antagonists: A mysterious plague on Dramia II
Political scapegoating of an off-world doctor

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise visits the planet Dramia to deliver medical supplies, only for McCoy to be abruptly arrested by local authorities. They accuse him of causing a deadly plague on their colony world, Dramia II, years earlier during a previous medical mission.

McCoy is charged with mass murder, and the Dramians insist on trying him under their laws. Kirk, convinced of his chief medical officer’s innocence, investigates the old records and learns that shortly after McCoy’s departure, a devastating epidemic swept the colony.

Determined to clear McCoy’s name, Kirk takes the Enterprise to Dramia II to search for survivors and clues. The planet is shrouded in storms and lingering environmental damage from the plague. When members of the landing party begin exhibiting symptoms, it becomes clear that the disease vector is still present.

Working from a cell with limited resources, McCoy analyzes blood samples and planetary data provided secretly by Spock and the crew. He identifies a natural cosmic radiation event as the true trigger of the illness and devises a treatment. Once the cure is administered to those infected, McCoy presents the evidence proving that the plague was not of his making.

The Dramians drop the charges and express gratitude for the cure, though the emotional scars from the epidemic remain. McCoy returns to the Enterprise slightly gruff but clearly moved, joking that he prefers being a country doctor to a defendant in an alien courtroom.

EthicalIssues: Assigning blame for natural disasters to convenient outsiders.
The vulnerability of humanitarian workers to retroactive accusations.
Due process and evidence in interstellar justice systems.
ContinuityNotes: Gives McCoy a rare spotlight in which his past off-screen missions drive the plot.
Adds Dramia and its colonies to the map of Federation-era worlds.
Echoes other Trek episodes dealing with plague, quarantine, and medical ethics.
ThematicNotes: Scapegoating in the aftermath of tragedy.
The importance of scientific investigation in uncovering truth.
Trust between shipmates when outside institutions turn against them.
BehindTheScenes: Animation allows depiction of dramatic planetary storms and plague-ravaged landscapes.
The episode foregrounds McCoy’s professionalism and tenacity under pressure.
Its courtroom and investigation structure fits within the classic Trek tradition of moral inquiry.

Title: How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth
Antagonists: An ancient alien posing as a god
Demand for worship in exchange for protection

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise follows a mysterious alien probe to an uncharted region of space, where a vast serpent-headed ship appears and ensnares the starship in an energy field. A booming voice accuses humanity of forgetting its 'creator.'

The being identifies itself as Kukulkan, a powerful alien who once visited Earth and other worlds, inspiring various serpent-god myths. Offended that modern civilizations no longer worship him, Kukulkan transports Kirk, Spock, McCoy, and Ensign Walking Bear into a carefully constructed environment combining architectural motifs from multiple ancient cultures.

The landing party realizes that Kukulkan is testing them with a puzzle based on aligning structures from Maya, Aztec, Chinese, and Egyptian designs. By solving the puzzle, they hope to gain leverage to negotiate for the Enterprise’s freedom and challenge Kukulkan’s demand for renewed adoration.

Kirk argues that while Kukulkan may have guided early societies, true growth requires cultures to stand on their own. Attempting to freeze development at an obedient stage is no kindness. Confronted with evidence that his 'children' have flourished independently, Kukulkan reluctantly accepts that his era as a god must end.

Releasing the Enterprise, Kukulkan departs into the depths of space, a saddened but wiser figure. Walking Bear reflects on the myths of his own people, now seen in a new light, while Kirk muses that no parent—human or alien—can hold onto their children forever.

EthicalIssues: Posing as a deity to shape the development of younger civilizations.
Demanding worship as repayment for early guidance.
The right of cultures to outgrow their 'gods.'
ContinuityNotes: Connects Star Trek’s universe to real-world Mesoamerican and other ancient myths.
Introduces Ensign Walking Bear, whose cultural knowledge aids in solving the puzzle.
Adds Kukulkan to Trek’s roster of powerful beings once mistaken for gods.
ThematicNotes: Parent-child dynamics mapped onto god and worshipper.
Letting go as an act of true care.
Reinterpreting mythology through a science-fiction lens.
BehindTheScenes: Won a Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Entertainment Children’s Series as part of TAS’s run.
Animation allows for elaborate, myth-inspired structures and Kukulkan’s serpent form.
The episode stands out for its direct engagement with Earth’s ancient cultures.

Title: The Counter-Clock Incident
Antagonists: A universe where time flows backwards
The inevitability of aging and retirement

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise transports Robert April, the Federation’s first starship captain, and his wife Sarah to a ceremony marking his mandatory retirement. En route, the ship encounters a runaway vessel plunging toward a nova, then follows it into a strange white void where physical laws invert.

Emerging on the other side of the anomaly, the crew finds themselves in a 'negative' universe where stars are black on a bright background and time runs in reverse. The runaway ship’s pilot, Karina, is rescued and explains that, in her space, they were heading away from danger, not toward it.

As the Enterprise continues deeper into this inverted realm, the crew begins to grow physically younger, regressing in age while retaining their memories—at least at first. Their voices change, uniforms hang loosely, and responsibilities become harder to manage as they approach childhood.

As Kirk and his officers grow too young to command effectively, Robert April and Sarah, also affected but starting from an older baseline, reach the prime of their lives. April resumes command, guiding the Enterprise back toward the anomaly’s origin point and calculating a course that will return them to the normal universe before they de-age into infancy.

Back in normal space, Starfleet restores the crew to their proper ages, though April and Sarah must relinquish their brief return to youth. Offered a chance to remain younger, April declines, accepting that his life’s work stands on its own and that new generations must take the helm.

EthicalIssues: Mandatory retirement for experienced officers regardless of capability.
Temptation to reclaim youth at the expense of the natural life cycle.
Interfering with inhabitants of an inverse universe for one’s own safety.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Robert April, the Enterprise’s first captain in Starfleet history.
Explores a rare visit to a 'reverse' universe with inverted physical laws.
Provides a canonical glimpse at earlier Federation history and starship command.
ThematicNotes: Aging, legacy, and the value of experience.
Youth and age as different vantage points on the same journey.
Accepting the passage of time rather than trying to undo it.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the final-produced episode of The Animated Series.
Uses animation to visualize an inverted universe and de-aging crew.
Robert April’s inclusion deepens Star Trek’s fictional Starfleet lineage.
